Materials and methods C57BL/6 mice were subjected to single thoracic X-ray irradiation at doses ranging from 5 to 30 Gy. Changes in body weight, daily food and water intake, and survival were monitored and compared within 2 weeks after radiation exposure. Epithelial damage to the esophagus, apoptosis, and inflammation at different times after irradiation were examined to characterize the pathological process of RIE. Results The incidence of acute RIE was strongly correlated with increasing radiation dose across all the experimental groups. No deaths were observed in mice that received 5 or 10 Gy of irradiation, whereas complete mortality was observed within 15 days after exposure to 30 Gy of irradiation. The mice in 20 Gy irradiation group had a low mortality rate. The peak of esophageal tissue damage occurred at Day 7 and was healed by Day 14 after exposure to 20 Gy of thoracic irradiation. The pathology of RIE was induced by radiation-induced DNA damage, apoptosis, reactive oxygen species (ROS), and mitochondrial impairment. Conclusions In this study, we found that a single 20 Gy thoracic irradiation was the optimal dose to establish acute RIE in C57BL/6 mice. Acute esophageal injury peaked on Day 7 after radiation, and the process of regeneration and repair was complete within 14 days. This work may be a useful reference for experimental research concerning RIE. Supplementary Information The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s13014-025-02720-w. Radiation-induced esophagitis (RIE) is the most frequent complication of radiotherapy for thoracic malignancies, such as lung cancer and esophageal cancer, with a high incidence ranging from 65 to 75%, and it accounts for nearly 100% of cases of esophageal cancer [ 1 2 3 4 5 Establishing an appropriate animal model is a fundamental step for understanding the pathology of clinical diseases and developing new therapeutic targets. The pathogenesis of ARIE has not been fully clarified until now, and it is potentially linked to direct DNA damage caused by radiation or the overproduction of free radicals and ROS generated by radiation interacting with intercellular water molecules [ 6 7 Currently, ARIE has been modeled in many animals, such as rabbits, rats, and mice. Rabbits are large enough to tolerate irradiations, and their esophageal tissues are readily accessible and straightforward to observe, rendering them an optimal animal model for ARIE. However, the high costs greatly increase the overall expense and limit their wide use. Rodents are currently the most widely used animals for RIE because of their high reproductive capacity, easy access to esophageal tissues, low prices, and greater options for genetic modification. For example, some studies established an ARIE model in C57BL/6 mice via single-dose irradiation at 25 Gy, and esophageal damage occurred after 5 days [ 8 9 10 60 11 12 15 131 14 Despite the context presented thus far, there is still a lack of consensus on the optimal radiation dosage to elicit ARIE in mice. In this study, we aimed to optimize the radiation dose for ARIE in mice to more closely reflect a similar process to that of clinical patients. We also characterized the pathological features of ARIE in mice, which revealed more specific intervention points for those different therapeutic strategies in the future. Methods and materials Animals Six to eight-week-old male C57BL/6 mice were obtained from HFK Bioscience Co., LTD (Beijing, China). Mice were accommodated in the specific pathogen-free (SPF) facility, subjected to a 12-h alternating light and dark schedule with access to water and food ad libitum. The experiments were conducted in accordance with the ethical standards outlined for laboratory animal research, and the protocols were licensed by Ethics Committee of Sichuan Cancer Hospital & Institute with the approval number SCCHEC-04–2023-014. Thoracic radiation protocol Radiation of mice was performed using X-RAD 320 irradiator (PXI, CT, USA). Briefly, mice were anesthetized with 1% (w/v) pentobarbital sodium solution and placed in trays covered with 1.5 mm Pb plate, and the exposure field between the base of the neck and the xiphoid process was adjusted to receive thorax irradiation. A single dose of X-ray radiation was delivered to the thorax, including the esophagus, bilateral lungs, and mediastinum, and the doses included 5 Gy, 10 Gy, 15 Gy, 20 Gy, 25 Gy, and 30 Gy. The dosing rate was 75 cGy/min., The radiation program was operated at 320 kV and 9 mA at a source-skin distance (SSD) of 50 cm from the target. Observation and tissue collection After thoracic irradiation, the general healthy status of mice was monitored for 14 days, including body weight, survival, and behavior activity. Daily food and water intakes were quantified during this period by measuring uneaten food and water levels in individual cages. Mice were euthanized by cervical dislocation to collect esophageal tissues on Day 3, Day 7, Day 10, and Day 14 after the irradiation. Histological analysis and Pathological score Esophageal tissues were excised, fixed in 4% cold paraformaldehyde (PFA), and embedded in paraffin following standard procedures. Sections with a thickness of 4 μm were deparaffinized and stained for hematoxylin–eosin (H&E), and then observed under the light microscope (Olympus BX53, Tokyo, Japan). Esophageal tissue damage and inflammatory cell infiltration were evaluated to determine the pathological alterations. The baseline for radiation esophagitis was a pathological score of 0, with the severity being determined by the cumulative score of tissue damage and inflammation [ 16 Immunostaining Esophageal sections were initially deparaffined by xylene and rehydrated by gradient ethanol. Subsequently, antigen retrieval was performed by boiling slides in Tris–EDTA Antigen Retrieval Solution (BL618A, Biosharp). And nonspecific binding was blocked using blocking buffer, which contained 1% solution of bovine serum albumin (BSA, A7906, Sigma-Aldrich) and 0.5% Triton X-100. Different primary antibodies were applied at a dilution of 1:200 and incubated at 4 °C overnight in the darkness. Primary antibodies utilized in this study encompassed mouse anti-proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA, Santa), rat anti-F4/80, mouse anti-cytokeratin 14 (CK14, Abcam), rabbit anti-phospho-histone H3 (PHH3), anti-γH2AX, anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO), and anti-CD3 (Cell Signaling Technology) antibodies. On the subsequent day, HRP-conjugated secondary antibody solution (ZSBio, Beijing, China) was applied, followed by visualization through immunohistochemistry (IHC) using DAB kit (ZSBio, Beijing, China). Nucleus were counterstained by hematoxylin. For immunofluorescence (IF), highly cross-adsorbed donkey anti-rabbit or mouse IgG (H + L) conjugated with Alexa Fluor™ 488 or 594 (ThermoFisher Scientific, USA) were used, and slides were counterstained with VECTASHIELD Antifade Mounting Medium containing 4′6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA). Images were captured using an Olympus BX53 microscope, or Zeiss Axio Observer equipped with Apotome3. One-Step TUNEL apoptosis assay Radiation-induced apoptosis of esophageal epithelial cells was demonstrated by One-Step TUNEL Apoptosis Kit (KeyGen Bio-Tech, Nanjing, China). Briefly, slides were dewaxed, rehydrated, and intestinal tissues treated with Proteinase K at 37 °C for 30 min. Subsequently, FITC-labelled TUNEL reaction solution was incubated for 1 h at 37 °C in the dark. Nuclei were counterstained with DAPI, and slides were mounted in antifade medium. Images were captured using a Zeiss Axio Observer with Apotome3. ROS detection assay Intracellular ROS levels were examined with Dihydroethidium (DHE) following the manufacture’s protocol (Beyotime, China). Briefly, fresh esophageal tissues on Day 3, Day 7, Day 10, and Day 14 after irradiation were directly embedded in OCT compound and frozen sections were prepared at -20℃. Frozen sections of 5 μm thickness were incubated in 10 mM DHE for 30 min at room temperature in dark, washed twice with PBS, and then observed using an inverted fluorescence microscope under the appropriate channel following the manufacture’s protocol. Quantitative RT-PCR Total RNA was extracted by RNAiso Plus (TaKaRa, Japan) per the manufacturer's protocol and quantified with a NanoDrop2000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific). cDNA was synthesized using Hifair II 1st Strand cDNA Synthesis SuperMix (YEASEN, China), followed by qPCR with Hief qPCR SYBR Green Master Mix (YEASEN) on a C1000 instrument (Bio-Rad, USA). mRNA expression levels of IL-1β, IL-6, IL-10, and TNFα were determined, and data were normalized to β-actin. Gene expression was calculated using 2 −ΔΔCt Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) Healthy and irradiated esophageal tissues were quickly removed and fixed for 1 h in cold 0.1 m sodium cacodylate–HCl buffer (pH 7.4) containing 4% PFA and 1% glutaraldehyde. After fixation, specimens were washed four times for 15 min in 0.1 m cacodylate buffer containing 0.1 m glycine. Esophageal samples were further postfixed in 1% osmium tetroxide in 0.1 m cacodylate buffer, dehydrated in a methanol series to propylene oxide, and embedded in epoxy resin. Ultrathin esophageal sections were placed on nickel grids for observation. Images were captured by Philips Tecnai-10 transmission electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. Statistical analysis Experimental data were presented as mean ± SD analyzed and analyzed by GraphPad Prism 9 (GraphPad Software, USA). The survival analysis data were analyzed using the Log-rank test. Other data were analyzed using One-way ANOVA, Brown-Forsythe ANOVA, and Two-way ANOVA, while multiple comparisons were conducted using Dunnett’s T3 multiple comparisons test and Tukey’s HSD test. A B C D E p p p p Epithelial injury of ARIE depends on the radiation dose Esophageal tissues were used for pathological analysis at Day 3, Day7, Day 10, and Day 14 after thorax irradiation. The cross section of the esophagus contained the mucosal epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae, followed by the submucosal layer, the muscularis propria, and finally, the adventitia (Figure S1). The esophageal epithelium, as a stratified nonkeratinizing squamous epithelium featuring a quintuple layered structure from bottom to top, is sequentially composed of the stratum base, stratum spinosum, stratum granulosum, stratum lucidum, and stratum corneum. Healthy esophagus contains 6–8 cellular layers. Compared with the control group, only minor thinning of the epithelial layer was noted on Day 3, without alterations in the keratin layer. By Day 7, both the epithelial and keratinized layers had severely shrunk with disrupted epithelial integrity, and the epithelial cells were swollen, necrotic, and detached, with a greatly reduced number of cells in layers 1–3. Additionally, vacuolation of the cells was observed, which is indicative of acute and severe injury. On Day 10, the esophageal epithelium was thicker than on Day 7, with well-aligned epithelial cells. However, there was significant infiltration of inflammatory cells in the submucosa, and no obvious thickening of the keratin layer was observed. On Day 14, the thickness of the esophageal epithelium was significantly greater than that in the control and early stages of ARIE. The number of cellular layers increased significantly to 7–10, and the size and morphology of the epithelial cells recovered to normal, indicating that the esophageal epithelium may be in a regenerative and repairing stage. A B C E p p p p # p ## p ### p #### p Discussion Esophageal injuries of different severities may be manifested in patients following radiotherapy for thoracic, and some head and neck, cancers, and such injuries include both acute and chronic effects due to the range of molecular reactions [ 27 29 6 9 30 31 Mice are the most widely used experimental model, and many well-established genetic resources are available. In this study, we compared X-ray irradiation-induced acute esophagitis in C57BL/6 mice via a wide range of single doses. We have chosen 6 to 8-week-old male C57BL/6 mice for this study in order to better simulate the clinical scenario of radiation esophagitis in human esophageal cancer, which is more prevalent in males [ 32 33 34 35 36 37 38 39 40 2 The progression of typical radiation injury involves five sequential stages: the injury initiation stage, the signal transduction stage, the signal amplification stage, the ulcer formation stage, and the healing and repair stage [ 41 42 3 4 6 B 6 43 44 45 46 In addition, esophageal injury in the 20 Gy group presented clear signs of regeneration and healing on Day 14, characterized by a notable increase in epithelial thickness, a diminished inflammatory response, and well-aligned basal cells. Moreover, both the number of inflammatory cells and the number of inflammatory factors were significantly lower at this time than on Day 7. On day 14, the increased thickness of the esophageal epithelium and the well-aligned basal cells, along with the recovery of CK14-positive stem cells, indicate that the esophageal tissue possesses a certain capacity for self-repair, which may be associated with the activation and proliferation of stem cells. Meanwhile, the significant reduction in the number of inflammatory cells and inflammatory factors, and the attenuation of the inflammatory response, provide a favorable microenvironment for tissue repair and reduce further damage to the tissue caused by inflammation [ 46 47 48 However, it can be observed from Fig. 3 49 54 50 50 49 51 49 51 52 53 54 Presently, the construction of animal models for ARIE predominantly utilizes rats, mice, and rabbits as experimental subjects. The prevailing experimental paradigm in the majority of studies involves administering a single high-dose irradiation regimen, while a few have attempted low-dose fractionated irradiation [ 8 10 13 11 12 55 56 Despite these interesting findings, there are still shortcomings in the current study. First, the model we established was relatively simple and did not explore the potential mechanisms of radiation damage and regeneration of the esophagus in depth, which will be further investigated in future studies. Second, we adopted only a single dose of X-ray irradiation for the purpose of operational convenience in establishing an experimental mouse model. Since fractioned irradiation is used in clinical practice, such an irradiation strategy will also be tested in the future. Finally, we used whole thoracic irradiation which may also damage some vital organs, such as the lung and heart, which can not exactly mimic clinical circumstances. Although this study mainly focuses on acute injury and repair, long-term fibrotic damage is also an issue that needs attention in the radiotherapy of esophageal cancer. Long-term fibrosis can lead to serious complications such as esophageal stricture, affecting patients' quality of life. In clinical practice, long-term follow-up of esophageal cancer patients receiving radiotherapy is necessary to monitor potential late complications and take timely intervention measures. Therefore, future research needs to further explore strategies for preventing and mitigating fibrosis. Conclusions Taken together, in this study, we optimized the doses of thoracic irradiation for acute radiation-induced esophagitis and found that 20 Gy of irradiation was the most ideal dose for establishing ARIE. We demonstrated the pathological process of esophageal epithelial injury in 20-Gy ARIE-treated mice and emphasized that the most severe epithelial injury occurred on Day 7 and that this injury regenerated by Day 14. Our findings might provide important laboratory evidence for future ARIE studies. Supplementary Information  Additional file 1.
